header.title: LEGENDS OF INCENSE, HERB & OIL MAGIC

central_thesis: The book posits that magic is a "definite religion" where supernatural power resides in natural objects (herbs, roots, oils, minerals). It teaches a system of practical magic based on Sympathetic and Contagious principles, emphasizing the practitioner's 'WILL and FAITH' as the true driving force behind rituals involving consecrated oils, incenses, herbs, and powders for diverse purposes, including attraction, commanding, protection, healing, and spiritual development. The methodology involves specific anointing patterns, burning protocols, and the creation of charms, often tied to ancient traditions and spiritual assistance.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER ONE: So-Called Oil and Perfume Magic
structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces the philosophical basis of oil and perfume magic, detailing the occult and psychic aspects of anointing. It explains the 'Holy Trinity' (Soul Trinity for White Magic) and 'Flesh Trinity' (for Black Magic) as foundational concepts for anointing patterns. It provides practical instructions on how to anoint oneself or objects, how to 'dress' a candle with oil for magical work, and descriptions of various magical oils like Magnet Oil, Healing Oil, Commanding Oil, Altar Oil, Lovers Oil, Attraction Oil, Rose of Crucifixion Oil, High Conquering Oil, Incense Oil, Spirit Oil, Lucky Planet Oil, and Black Art Oil, outlining their intended magical effects.

This chapter continues the exploration of specific magical oils and their traditional uses. It describes oils such as King Solomon Oil (for wisdom and power), Ten Commandment Oil (for consecration), Temple Oil (for concentration and psychic development), Indian Guide Oil (for connecting with spirit guides), Compelling Oil (to influence others), Exodus Oil (to be pleasing to the Holy Spirit), Power Oil (for influence and control), Hindu Grass, Angel Oil (to attract spirits), Dove's Blood Brand Oil (for white magic), Bible Bouquet Oil (for receiving divine help), Five Circle Oil, Bat's Blood (for black magic), Chinese Oil, Holy Spirit Baths, Concentration Oil, Buddha Oil, and Cleopatra Oil (for allure and influence).

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER THREE: Love Powders, Potions, Philtres
structure_content.summary: This chapter delves into the history and practical application of love magic, focusing on powders, potions, and philtres. It recounts historical anecdotes and provides recipes for 'True Love Powder,' 'Curious Water of Myrtle Flowers,' 'Angel Water,' 'Curious Water Known by the Name of the Spring Nosegay,' 'Tincture of Ambergris,' and 'Water of Chastity.' The text discusses ingredients, preparation methods, and the intended effects of these love-related magical concoctions, drawing from various cultural and historical sources.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER FOUR: Three Reasons for Using Incense
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the historical and ceremonial uses of incense across Hebrew, Egyptian, and Hindu traditions, identifying three primary reasons for its use: pleasing deities, masking odors, and carrying petitions. It details the preparation of liquid incenses and specific powdered incenses, including Oriental Incense, Abtina Incense, Ceremonial Incense, Mystic-Rites Incense, Black Incense, Master's Oriental Incense, Temple Incense, Magnet Incense, Lovers Incense, Attraction Incense, Commanding Incense, Cleopatra Incense, Compelling Incense, Spirit Incense, Lucky Planet Incense, Concentration Incense, Power Incense, and Success Incense, often with formulas for their making.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER FIVE: Information on Herbs, Flowers, and Trees
structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces the 'Doctrine of Signatures' as a method for discerning the medicinal and magical properties of plants based on their appearance. It recounts various legends and myths associated with specific plants, flowers, and trees from different cultures (e.g., lady's slipper, hawthorn, mistletoe), detailing their historical and symbolic significance in rituals, healing, and charms, and distinguishing between those associated with beneficial and malevolent influences.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER SIX: Herbs Used in Magic
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides an extensive catalog of specific herbs and roots used in various magical practices. For each entry, it describes traditional beliefs and applications, such as Queen Elizabeth Root (for answering questions), Orris Root (for attracting love), Buckeye (for luck/rheumatism), High John the Conqueror (for protection/conquering), Adam & Eve Root (for holding love), Dragon's Blood (for uncrossing), and Graveyard Dust (for baneful magic), among many others. It highlights their roles in folk magic and occult traditions.

This chapter focuses on the folklore and magical properties of specific plants like Elder, Fern, and Mistletoe. It details legends surrounding the Elder's spirit and its use in protective magic, the fern's ability to unlock fetters or grant invisibility (fern-seed), and the Mistletoe's sacred status among Druids, its protective qualities against evil, and its role in healing. The chapter emphasizes the deep-rooted cultural beliefs and rituals associated with these botanicals.

This chapter defines and describes sachet powders as mixtures of finely ground ingredients used in magical work, often enclosed in cloth bags or placed with personal items. It distinguishes powders from 'extracts' and details the general composition, emphasizing the 'body' (e.g., orris root, rose petals) and 'odorous agents.' It also provides insights into the quality of ingredients and the process of trituration for proper mixing, mentioning 'Occult Sachet Powders' for specific magical uses.

This chapter provides practical formulas for various preparations, including 'White Lavender,' 'Red Lavender,' and 'Chinese Wash.' It also describes 'Baume Tranquille,' a French Codex preparation for its calming properties, and outlines a modern formula revision for it. The chapter concludes with instructions for 'Bush Baths, Herb Baths, and Condition Baths,' detailing the ingredients and method for preparing these ritual baths for cleansing and influencing.

key_concepts.definition: Magic based on the 'association of ideas by similarity,' where acting upon an image or likeness of something is believed to affect the actual thing (e.g., piercing a doll to harm a person).

Magic based on the 'association of ideas by contiguity,' where objects once in contact with a person or thing are believed to retain a magical connection and can be used to influence it (e.g., using hair or nail parings).

The philosophy that magic is a 'definite religion' where supernatural power is inherent in natural objects and products (herbs, roots, oils, minerals), capable of saving or destroying life, and influencing destiny.
The esoteric idea that the practitioner's 'WILL and FAITH' are the true, underlying forces behind all magical ceremonies, rites, incantations, amulets, and charms, making them effective.

The formula for White Magic, represented by a triangle pointing upwards. It governs the 'Soul Region' (diaphragm to head) and influences aspects like vision, holiness, religion, higher love, benign spirit forces, mind, concentration, healing, mediumship, and clairvoyance.

The formula for Black Magic, represented by a triangle pointing downwards. It governs the 'Flesh Trinity' (breast, stomach, sex region, bowels) and influences aspects like witchcraft, lust, evil spirits, demonacal possession, evil influence, spells, black art, crossed conditions, and unholy vibrations.

The practical act of rubbing or applying consecrated oils to oneself, another person, or magical objects (like candles, photographs), following specific triangular patterns to draw out negative influences or to infuse desired magical qualities and magnetism.

The sacred secret of anointing a candle with oil and impressing one's wishes upon it, thereby 'magnetizing' it and imparting 'tremendous forces' for occult uses. This process is distinct from merely using a candle of a particular color.

A historical system for discovering the medicinal and magical uses of plants by observing their external appearance, as it was believed plants resembled the diseases or conditions they could cure or influence (e.g., aspen leaves shaking like palsy).

The energetic quality or essence believed to be present in natural objects and magical preparations (oils, incenses), which can affect human consciousness, emotions, and circumstances, often described in terms of aroma influencing a 'desire' or 'harmony.'

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined by Lewis de Claremont involves the preparation and consecration of various magical materials—oils, incenses, herbs, and powders—which are then utilized in specific rituals to effect desired changes. Central to the system is the understanding of two Trinities: the 'Holy Inner Trinity' for White Magic (beneficial purposes) and the 'Lower Trinity' for Black Magic (baneful or controlling purposes). Practitioners are instructed to align their intention ('WILL and FAITH') with the chosen materials and anointing patterns to direct spiritual vibrations and magnetism. This system is heavily operative, focusing on the manipulation of natural and supernatural energies through tangible items.
tools: Magical Oils (e.g., Magnet Oil, Commanding Oil, Lovers Oil, King Solomon Oil, Black Art Oil, Concentration Oil)
Magical Incenses (e.g., Oriental Incense, Black Incense, Lucky Planet Incense, Power Incense)
Herbs and Roots (e.g., Queen Elizabeth Root, Orris Root, High John the Conqueror, Adam & Eve Root, Dragon's Blood, Mistletoe, Rosemary, Frankincense, Gum Myrrh)
Sachet Powders (custom blends for various effects)
Muslin or chamois bags (for carrying charms)
Bible (for specific Psalms to be recited)
Loadstones and metallic dust (for magnetizing preparations)
Bowls, metal pans, jars, alembics (for mixing and storing materials)
rituals: Anointing oneself or others with specific oils, following triangular patterns (upwards for White Magic/Soul Trinity, downwards for Black Magic/Flesh Trinity) to draw out or infuse influence, often accompanied by Psalms or prayers.
Dressing candles by anointing them with oils from the center outwards (up for North Pole, down for South Pole), impressing wishes, and magnetizing them with faith.
Burning liquid incenses (e.g., alcohol mixed with incense oil) in a bowl, uttering specific incantations ('Tetragramaton') while holding hands outstretched over the flame.
Burning powdered incenses (often mixed with oils) for various purposes like attracting good spirits, inducing clairvoyance, concentration, or carrying petitions to deities.
Carrying specific herbs, roots, or charms (e.g., High John the Conqueror, Tonka Beans) in bags or on the person for luck, protection, or attraction.
Performing ritual baths with herb and oil mixtures (e.g., Holy Spirit Baths, Bush Baths) for cleansing, protection, or attracting desired conditions.
Using oils or incenses in specific locations (altars, homes, on clothing, on wood) to draw or repel energies, often with visualizations or chanting.
Writing wishes or names on parchment and anointing them with oils, often placing them with candles for extended workings.

relevant_quotes.text: It is said that the underlying secret of the magic that resulted from the use of material things such as roots, herbs, oils, etc., is based upon the Law of Sympathy.

MAGIC IS A DEFINITE RELIGION whether it is Black Magic or White Magic and to the honest open minded student it is as pure a religion intrinsically as most recognized beliefs. For instance: in the religion of our every day civilized life man is given supernatural powers as in the case of the Priest in whom lies the power of making water holy, which in turn is able to sanctify a person...

The true magical secrets of compounds and formulas... back of all the ceremonies, rites and incantations was the esoteric idea that the WILL and FAITH was the real force employed under the mask of incantations and rites assumed to impress the imaginations and minds of the populace.

All magical anointing has its foundation upon this Trinity which is called the Holy Inner Trinity and also all rubbing and laying on of hands for healing or influencing must follow the form of the triangle, so that the magnetism thus produced shall have its proper mesmeric vibration.
But when you anoint the candle with oil and impress upon it your wishes you then magnetise it with your faith; the candle receives tremendous forces and is ready for your occult uses.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant to the study of practical Western Esotericism, particularly within American folk magic traditions like Hoodoo and Conjure, which often incorporate elements from various ethnic and spiritual practices. Lewis de Claremont's work synthesizes ceremonial magic principles (e.g., the Trinities, consecration, planetary influences) with the practical application of roots, herbs, oils, and incenses common in folk magic. It provides a unique perspective on the operative side of magic, emphasizing the practitioner's inner faculties (Will and Faith) as crucial alongside the material tools, thus bridging psychological and tangible aspects of magical work. The detailed descriptions of specific oils and incenses, coupled with their alleged effects and traditional uses, offer valuable insight into the syncretic nature of magical practice in the early to mid-20th century.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for 'Legends of Incense, Herb & Oil Magic' includes practitioners and scholars of Western Esotericism, particularly those interested in practical magic, folk magic traditions (Hoodoo, Conjure), and spiritual supplies. It is also valuable for individuals seeking historical context on the use of botanical and aromatic materials in magical and religious rites, and those interested in self-help through esoteric methods, particularly involving anointing, incense burning, and charm-making as a means of influencing personal circumstances and spiritual development.
